snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has enjoyed a close relationship with the financial sector, must grapple with a powerful populist surge coursing through national politics, on both the right and the left.
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton's close ties to Wall Street will be scrutinized if she runs for president in 2016; she must grapple with a powerful populist surge coursing through national politics, on both the right and the left; at stake is not merely tens of millions of dollars in campaign money, but the shape of debates about social mobility, taxation and regulation.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and AMY CHOZICK

lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has enjoyed a close relationship with the financial sector, must grapple with a powerful populist surge coursing through national politics, on both the right and the left.

headline.main: Wall Street Offers Clinton a Thorny Embrace
headline.print_headline: Wall Street Offers Clinton a Thorny Embrace
